epidemiology: Common in children under 5 years. Peak between 6–18 months. Often follows URTI.

treatment.protocol: Start antibiotics if symptoms persist >48 hrs or if <2 years. Follow-up in 10–14 days.

epidemiology: Peak in infants <2 years, especially in winter. RSV is the commonest cause.

supportive: Nasogastric feeds if unable to feed
definitive: Supportive only; no antibiotics unless superinfection suspected
treatment.protocol: Admit if feeding poorly or hypoxic. Oxygen if SpO₂ <90%. Monitor closely.

epidemiology: Highly contagious viral illness. Unvaccinated children at highest risk.

definitive: No antiviral; isolation and supportive care
treatment.protocol: Give Vitamin A 200,000 IU once daily for 2 days. Isolate for at least 5 days after rash appears.

epidemiology: Occur in children aged 6 months–5 years. Triggered by high fever. Often benign.

others: Lumbar puncture if <18 months or suspicious symptoms

definitive: Diazepam rectal gel for prolonged seizures
treatment.protocol: If seizure <5 mins: no meds. >5 mins: diazepam. Investigate if atypical features present.

epidemiology: Common in under-5s. Viral causes dominate (rotavirus, norovirus). High morbidity in low-resource settings.

definitive: Antibiotics only for bacterial causes (e.g., Shigella)
treatment.protocol: Mild: ORS. Severe: IV fluids. Zinc 10–20 mg/day for 10–14 days.

epidemiology: Affects unvaccinated or partially vaccinated children. Caused by Bordetella pertussis.

treatment.protocol: Start antibiotics early in catarrhal phase. Isolate for 5 days after treatment starts.

epidemiology: Major cause of mortality in under-5s worldwide. Can be viral or bacterial.

treatment.protocol: Treat mild cases with oral antibiotics. Admit severe cases for IV therapy and monitoring.

epidemiology: Affects 60% of term and 80% of preterm newborns. Most cases are physiologic.

treatment.protocol: Start phototherapy if bilirubin > threshold. Monitor levels. Escalate to transfusion if no improvement.

epidemiology: Highly contagious skin infestation. Common in crowded environments.

treatment.protocol: Apply permethrin overnight, repeat in 1 week. Treat all close contacts.

epidemiology: Most common nutritional deficiency in children. Peak incidence in toddlers and adolescent girls.

emergency_markers: Severe pallor with tachycardia or breathlessness

treatment.protocol: Give ferrous sulfate 3–6 mg/kg/day. Continue for 3 months after correction. Monitor Hb and ferritin.

epidemiology: Affects all age groups but more common in neonates and young children. Bacterial causes are most severe.

others: CT brain if raised ICP suspected

treatment.protocol: Start empiric antibiotics immediately. Adjust based on culture. Admit for monitoring.

epidemiology: Most common glomerular disorder in children. Peak onset 2–6 years. Usually minimal change disease.

treatment.protocol: Start corticosteroids. Monitor urine protein. Taper slowly over weeks. Treat relapses similarly.

epidemiology: Very common in school-aged children. Mostly viral but can be bacterial (Group A strep).

treatment.protocol: Treat strep with 10-day antibiotics. Supportive care for viral cases. Tonsillectomy for recurrent.

epidemiology: Common in under-5s. Major cause of child mortality in low-resource settings.

treatment.protocol: Give IV fluids per WHO Plan C. Monitor vitals. Continue ORS. Give zinc for 10–14 days.

epidemiology: May be congenital or acquired. Common causes: aqueductal stenosis, infection, hemorrhage.

treatment.protocol: Refer to neurosurgery. Imaging confirmation. Schedule shunt. Monitor for complications.

epidemiology: Very common in children, especially during toilet training or school entry. Often functional.

treatment.protocol: Disimpaction if needed, followed by maintenance therapy and behavioral changes.

epidemiology: Affects up to 20% of children. Often associated with other atopic conditions like asthma.

others: Allergy testing if severe or persistent

treatment.protocol: Emollients multiple times daily. Mild steroids for flares. Treat infections promptly.

epidemiology: Highly contagious viral disease in children. Caused by varicella-zoster virus.

others: PCR or direct fluorescent antibody test if uncertain

treatment.protocol: Isolate until all lesions crust. Acyclovir if immunocompromised or severe disease.

epidemiology: Common in infants and young girls. May be first sign of urinary tract anomaly.

treatment.protocol: Treat with antibiotics for 7–10 days. Investigate structural anomalies if recurrent.

epidemiology: Common chronic respiratory condition in children. Often triggered by allergens or infections.

treatment.protocol: Stepwise management. SABA for rescue. ICS for control. Oral steroids for exacerbations.

epidemiology: Common in tropical regions. Mosquito-borne viral illness affecting children during rainy seasons.

treatment.protocol: Avoid NSAIDs. Monitor for warning signs. Admit if platelet count <100,000 or symptoms severe.

epidemiology: Common in endemic regions. Caused by Plasmodium falciparum in most severe cases.

treatment.protocol: Uncomplicated: ACT. Severe: IV artesunate. Monitor Hb and treat complications.

epidemiology: Common in areas with poor sanitation. Caused by Salmonella typhi.

treatment.protocol: Start empiric antibiotics. Adjust per sensitivity. Admit if toxic or complications suspected.

epidemiology: Common vasculitis in children <5 years. More common in boys and Asian ethnicity.

treatment.protocol: Administer IVIG 2 g/kg over 12 hrs. High-dose aspirin. Monitor coronary arteries.

epidemiology: Caused by Group A Streptococcus. Occurs in children 5–15 years after pharyngitis.

treatment.protocol: 10-day penicillin course. Educate on hygiene. Monitor for complications.

epidemiology: Common in children under 5 years. Often follows acute otitis media or URTI.

treatment.protocol: Observe for 3 months. Refer for audiology. Insert tubes if no improvement or speech delay.

epidemiology: Most common chromosomal abnormality. Risk increases with maternal age.

treatment.protocol: Refer to specialists early. Screen for comorbidities. Monitor growth and development.

epidemiology: Common cause of intestinal obstruction in infants 6–18 months. Often idiopathic.

treatment.protocol: Stabilize first. Attempt enema reduction. Surgery if signs of peritonitis or failed reduction.

epidemiology: Autoimmune disease triggered by gluten in genetically predisposed individuals.

treatment.protocol: Strict gluten-free diet. Monitor growth and antibody levels. Screen family members.

epidemiology: X-linked enzymopathy affecting RBCs. Common in African, Mediterranean, and Asian populations.

treatment.protocol: Prevent exposure to oxidants. Transfuse if Hb dangerously low. Screen family if needed.

epidemiology: Highly contagious bacterial infection. Common in infants not fully vaccinated.

treatment.protocol: Treat with macrolide. Isolate for 5 days. Supportive care for cough and apnea.

epidemiology: Hypertrophy of pyloric muscle causing gastric outlet obstruction. Common in firstborn males.

timeline.symptom: Weight loss or poor weight gain

treatment.protocol: Stabilize first. Surgery after correction. Excellent prognosis post-op.

epidemiology: Very common in infants due to moisture and friction in diaper area.

treatment.protocol: Apply zinc oxide barrier. Add antifungal if no improvement in 3 days.

epidemiology: Affects under-5 children in low-resource settings. WHO classification used.

timeline.symptom: Visible wasting or bilateral pedal edema

treatment.protocol: Stabilize first 2–7 days. Transition to catch-up growth. Monitor for complications.

epidemiology: Common in school-aged children. Often viral, but bacterial cases require antibiotics.

treatment.protocol: 10-day antibiotic course for strep. Consider tonsillectomy if recurrent.

epidemiology: Highly contagious viral infection in children. More severe in adolescents and adults.

others: PCR or direct fluorescent antibody test if atypical

treatment.protocol: Isolate until lesions crust. Treat high-risk patients with antivirals.

epidemiology: Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells. Commonest in adolescents.

treatment.protocol: Start basal-bolus insulin. Educate on DKA signs. Regular HbA1c monitoring.

epidemiology: Mild viral exanthem. Dangerous during pregnancy due to congenital rubella syndrome.

treatment.protocol: Isolate for 7 days after rash onset. Supportive care only.

epidemiology: X-linked recessive bleeding disorder. Deficiency of factor VIII. Affects males.

treatment.protocol: Prophylactic factor VIII infusion. Emergency factor replacement for trauma.

epidemiology: Most common congenital heart defect. Varies in size and hemodynamic effect.

treatment.protocol: Small VSDs may close spontaneously. Treat symptoms. Surgery if persistent shunt.

epidemiology: Common viral illness in young children caused by coxsackievirus. Spreads in childcare settings.

timeline.symptom: Vesicular rash on hands and feet

treatment.protocol: Supportive care. Isolate during contagious phase. Monitor hydration.

epidemiology: Acute febrile vasculitis of childhood. Common in <5 years. Leading cause of acquired heart disease.

treatment.protocol: Administer IVIG within 10 days of fever. Monitor heart with serial echos.

epidemiology: Highly contagious viral disease. Preventable by vaccination.

treatment.protocol: Administer Vitamin A. Supportive care. Isolate for at least 4 days after rash onset.

epidemiology: Autoimmune destruction of platelets, often post-viral. Most common cause of thrombocytopenia in children.

treatment.protocol: Treat if platelets <20,000 or bleeding. Avoid NSAIDs and IM injections.

epidemiology: Caused by Sarcoptes scabiei mite. Spreads via close contact.

treatment.protocol: Apply permethrin overnight. Wash all bedding/clothes. Treat all close contacts.

epidemiology: Inflammation of external auditory canal, often bacterial. Common in swimmers.

emergency_markers: Severe ear pain with cranial nerve palsy

treatment.protocol: Clean ear canal. Apply topical antibiotics. Avoid moisture.

epidemiology: Immune-mediated renal inflammation after Group A strep infection. Peak age 5–12 years.

definitive: Treat underlying strep (penicillin), monitor renal function
treatment.protocol: Support BP and fluid balance. Most recover fully. Rarely need dialysis.

epidemiology: Viral illness with parotid gland swelling. Affects unvaccinated school-aged children.

treatment.protocol: Supportive care. Prevent with MMR vaccine. Monitor for complications.

epidemiology: Non-progressive motor disorder from brain injury before, during, or after birth.

treatment.protocol: Multidisciplinary care. Focus on function and prevention of complications.

epidemiology: Common in toddlers exploring environment. Most pass spontaneously.

timeline.symptom: History of ingestion or witnessed event

others: Endoscopy if symptomatic or high-risk object

treatment.protocol: Assess location and type of object. Endoscopy for batteries, magnets, sharp items.

epidemiology: Seizures occurring in 6 months to 5 years of age with fever, without CNS infection.

treatment.protocol: Simple febrile seizures require no long-term treatment. Educate caregivers.

epidemiology: Excess CSF accumulation in ventricles. Can be congenital or acquired.

treatment.protocol: Surgical CSF diversion. Long-term follow-up for shunt function.

epidemiology: Common in first week of life. Physiologic vs pathologic causes.

treatment.protocol: Treat based on age-specific bilirubin nomogram. Monitor neuro status.

epidemiology: Screened at birth. Can cause irreversible neurodevelopmental delay if untreated.

treatment.protocol: Start within first 2 weeks of life. Adjust dose based on TSH and T4.

epidemiology: Most common cause of hospitalization in infants <1 year. RSV is main pathogen.

definitive: No specific antiviral; palivizumab for prevention in high-risk
treatment.protocol: Supportive care. Admit if respiratory distress. Monitor closely in infants.
